issue.title: Dynamic objects force each other into the ground.
Dynamic objects force each other into the ground.

content.raw:
I think the non-realistic inertia of the default cubes also plays a role here. For example, I tested this world with a "properly-inertialized"™ cube:

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="box">
      <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <inertial>
          <mass>10</mass>
          <inertia>
            <ixx>1.666</ixx>
            <iyy>1.666</iyy>
            <izz>1.666</izz>
          </inertia>
        </inertial>
        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
          <material>
            <script>Gazebo/WoodPallet</script>
          </material>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
~~~

Then:

1. Inserted a cube from the toolbar (the grey one)
1. Inserted two cameras
1. Waited for both cubes to auto disable
1. Paused simulation and placed each camera above each cube, but 100 m on Z
1. Pressed play, each camera dropped on a different cube
1. You can see that the grey cube slowly sinks while the white one doesn't

![dropcamera.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1282510287-dropcamera.gif)
content.html:
I think the non-realistic inertia of the default cubes also plays a role here. For example, I tested this world with a "properly-inertialized"™ cube:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="box">
      <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <inertial>
          <mass>10</mass>
          <inertia>
            <ixx>1.666</ixx>
            <iyy>1.666</iyy>
            <izz>1.666</izz>
          </inertia>
        </inertial>
        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
          <material>
            <script>Gazebo/WoodPallet</script>
          </material>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

Then:

  1. Inserted a cube from the toolbar (the grey one)
  2. Inserted two cameras
  3. Waited for both cubes to auto disable
  4. Paused simulation and placed each camera above each cube, but 100 m on Z
  5. Pressed play, each camera dropped on a different cube
  6. You can see that the grey cube slowly sinks while the white one doesn't

issue.title: Dynamic objects force each other into the ground.

content.raw: Ah, nice! So is the problem not worth fixing? Or should we change the default shapes to have correct inertia values? Also, does fixing [this kind of behavior](https://youtu.be/5ABC2tDiarE) also depend on using the correct inertia?
content.html: Ah, nice! So is the problem not worth fixing? Or should we change the default shapes to have correct inertia values? Also, does fixing this kind of behavior also depend on using the correct inertia?

issue.title: Dynamic objects force each other into the ground.

content.raw:
I think this is still a valid issue, because sinking into the ground is definitely wrong.

I think the simple shapes inertia problem is covered by issue #1467.

As for the video, that looks more like an issue to be fixed with surface parameters than inertia, but I could be wrong.
content.html:
I think this is still a valid issue, because sinking into the ground is definitely wrong.

I think the simple shapes inertia problem is covered by issue #1467.

As for the video, that looks more like an issue to be fixed with surface parameters than inertia, but I could be wrong.
